source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4 show significant differences in response to heat treatment in the high alpha phase region; only Zircaloy-2 shows improvement in nodular corrosion resistance.
process_step: heat treatment in high alpha phase region

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: Both alloys, however, become highly resistant to nodular corrosion after receiving heat treatment in the alpha-beta or beta phase fields at temperatures above 830°C
process_step: heat treatment in alpha-beta or beta phase fields

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: direct fast neutron irradiation of Zircaloy is also needed to cause nodular corrosion at temperatures near 573K

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: Many studies of the nodular corrosion behavior of Zircaloy have been performed in ex-reactor steam tests at near 500°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: Cheng et al. [7,8] have demonstrated that the relative susceptibility of Zircaloy to in-reactor nodular corrosion can be properly ranked by using a 410/510°C two-step steam test

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: Cheng et al. [7,8] have demonstrated that the relative susceptibility of Zircaloy to in-reactor nodular corrosion can be properly ranked by using a 410/510°C two-step steam test

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk2
evidence_span: Zircaloy with a stringer-like precipitate distribution had poor corrosion resistance in near 500°C steam

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk2
evidence_span: The nodular corrosion resistance of alpha-recrystallized Zircaloy in 500°C steam can be further improved by a heat treatment in the alpha-beta or beta phase field at temperatures above 825°C
process_step: heat treatment in alpha-beta or beta phase field

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk2
evidence_span: heat treatment in the alpha-beta or beta phase field at temperatures above 825°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk2
evidence_span: fine precipitates that provide good electronic conductivity in the oxide formed on heat-treated Zircaloy were found by Cheng et al. [4] to have substantially dissolved after receiving a fast fluence of less than 1×10²¹ n/cm² (E > 1 MeV)

evidence_span: Visual examination of the samples after exposure to 510°C steam for 4 h and a cumulative time of 8, 12, and 16 h was performed.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk3
evidence_span: the sizes of the nodules are mostly the same, namely, ~0.9 mm after a total of 16 h exposure.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk3
evidence_span: The number of small nodules that will grow to large size has been shown in Ref 7 to increase with increasing severity of the test parameters, such as temperature and pressure, but not with test time.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk3

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk3
evidence_span: Before exposure to steam testing, the samples were chemically etched in a solution containing 2% concentrated HF, 45% HNO3, and the balance distilled water.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_033_chunk9
evidence_span: The level of solute content in the matrix is the key chemical/metallurgical factor in controlling nodular corrosion, with local areas of low solute concentration being the nodule nucleation sites
